data.q: Which Node.js core module is used to interact with the file system?
data.explanation: The fs module provides APIs for reading, writing, and managing files and directories.

data.q: Which fs method is used to read a file asynchronously?
data.explanation: fs.readFile reads the entire contents of a file asynchronously.

data.q: What is the key advantage of using asynchronous fs methods?
data.explanation: Asynchronous methods do not block the event loop, allowing Node.js to handle multiple operations efficiently.

data.q: Which fs method is used to write data to a file?
data.explanation: fs.writeFile writes data to a file, replacing the file if it already exists.

data.q: Which object provides access to command-line arguments passed to a Node.js script?
data.explanation: process.argv contains an array of command-line arguments passed to the Node.js process.
process.env stores the environment variables available to the Node.js process.

data.q: Which method terminates the Node.js process?
data.explanation: process.exit() immediately ends the Node.js process with an optional exit code.

data.q: What does an exit code of 0 indicate?
data.explanation: An exit code of 0 conventionally means the process exited successfully.

data.q: Which fs method adds data to the end of a file?
data.explanation: fs.appendFile appends data to a file without overwriting existing content.

data.q: Why should process.exit() be used carefully?
o: It may terminate pending asynchronous operations
data.explanation: Calling process.exit() can stop the event loop immediately, preventing pending async tasks from completing.
